support_summary: Calreticulin (CALR) is a soluble ER lectin chaperone that directly binds to the glycosylated luminal domain of ATF6. This interaction is a key part of the ER quality control system, repressing ATF6 activity by retaining it in the ER under non-stress conditions, thus preventing its transport to the Golgi for activation.

functions.cellular_process: The soluble ER lectin chaperone Calreticulin (CALR) binds to N-linked glycans on the luminal domain of newly synthesized ATF6, acting as a selective repressor of the ATF6 signaling pathway.
functions.effect_description: Calreticulin binding retains ATF6 in the endoplasmic reticulum, which inhibits its stress-induced trafficking to the Golgi apparatus and subsequent proteolytic activation.
biological_consequence: Calreticulin binds to N-linked glycans on the luminal domain of ATF6 → ATF6 is retained within the Endoplasmic Reticulum → ATF6 transport to the Golgi apparatus is blocked → Proteolytic cleavage and activation of ATF6 are prevented → ATF6 signaling pathway is repressed
specific_effects: Directly interacts with the luminal domain of ATF6α in vitro and in cells.
Depletion of Calreticulin results in constitutive activation, trafficking, and processing of ATF6.
Functions as a key repressor of ATF6α signaling under basal, non-stress conditions.
